questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient is having complaints of loss of vision in the form of a curtain coming down in front of the right eye. He has a history of 2 episodes of strokes, after which he has left-sided sensory and motor loss limited to the face and neck. Which of the following blood vessels might be stenosed in this case?

options.label: C
options.text: First part of the left subclavian artery

questions.text: A 67-year-old male was having complaints of sudden onset of severe chest pain, which was radiating to his back, and suddenly, he went unconscious. He was chronically hypertensive, a drug defaulter, and was having weakness, dizziness and dyspnea for 1 day. His current BP is 90/50 mm Hg, and his Heart Rate is 140 bpm. What is the best investigation of choice in this condition?
Which of the following signs is seen in Arteriovenous fistula?

A 35-year-old female experiences numbness and tingling in her right arm, worsened by arm elevation. During examination, she abducts her arms to 90° with external rotation, flexes her elbows to 90°, and opens and closes her hands for 3 minutes, which reproduces her symptoms. Which test was most likely performed?
questions.explanation:
Test

Maneuver

Result

Adson's Test (Option A)

Arm abducted 30° and maximally extended. Patient extends neck, turns head toward the ipsilateral side, and inhales deeply.

Decrease or absence of ipsilateral radial pulse.

Elevated Arm Stress Test (EAST) / Roos Test (Option B)

Arms in "surrender" position (abducted 90°, external rotation, elbows flexed 90°).

The patient slowly opens and closes hands for 3 minutes.

Pain, paresthesia, heaviness, or weakness precipitated.

Upper Limb Tension Test (ULTT) / Elvey Test (Option D)
  • Position 1: Arms abducted 90°, elbows flexed.
  • Position 2: Active dorsiflexion of wrists.
  • Position 3: Tilt head (ear to shoulder) in both directions.

Symptoms in the ipsilateral arm (Position 1 & 2); Contralateral symptoms in Position 3.

Test

Maneuver

Result

Adson's Test (Option A)

Arm abducted 30° and maximally extended. Patient extends neck, turns head toward the ipsilateral side, and inhales deeply.

Decrease or absence of ipsilateral radial pulse.

Elevated Arm Stress Test (EAST) / Roos Test (Option B)

Arms in "surrender" position (abducted 90°, external rotation, elbows flexed 90°).

The patient slowly opens and closes hands for 3 minutes.

Pain, paresthesia, heaviness, or weakness precipitated.

Upper Limb Tension Test (ULTT) / Elvey Test (Option D)
  • Position 1: Arms abducted 90°, elbows flexed.
  • Position 2: Active dorsiflexion of wrists.
  • Position 3: Tilt head (ear to shoulder) in both directions.

Symptoms in the ipsilateral arm (Position 1 & 2); Contralateral symptoms in Position 3.

questions.text: A 23-year-old competitive swimmer presents with progressive weakness and tingling in his right hand. On examination, there is wasting of the small muscles of the hand and sensory loss in the medial side of the hand and forearm. Which of the following nerves is most likely compressed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Boundaries
  • Upper: Collarbone (Clavicle)
  • Lower: First Rib
  • Anterior: Scalenus Anterior Muscle
  • Posterior: Scalenus Medius Muscle
  • Medial: Scalene Triangle (formed by the Scalenus Anterior, Scalenus Medius, and First Rib)

Predisposing Factors

Cervical Rib, Cervical Hematoma (Trauma), Pancoast Tumor, Osteoarthritis, Long Transverse Process of C7

Clinical Manifestations
  • Neurogenic TOS: Pain, numbness, and tingling due to nerve compression
  • Arterial TOS: Pain, coldness, and paleness due to impaired arterial blood flow
  • Venous TOS: Swelling, pain, and discolouration due to impaired venous return

questions.text: Which of the following is the most preferred vascular graft for CABG?

A 48-year-old male presents with retrosternal chest pain, which was radiation to the left arm and shoulder. He has a previous history of acute myocardial infarction. CABG was advised, but the patient is insisting on using synthetic graft and wants to know more about it. Which of the following is the most preferred synthetic vascular graft for CABG?
Based on the Stanford classification, which type of aortic dissection is shown below?
questions.explanation:
DeBakey Classification

(Based on the pattern of dissection)

Type I

Both ascending and descending aorta are involved

Type II

Only the ascending aorta is involved

Type III

Only the descending aorta is involved

Stanford Classification

(Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection)

Type A

Only the ascending aorta or both ascending and descending aorta is involved. (Option A)

(It includes both Type I and Type II of DeBakey’s classification)

Type B

Only the descending aorta is involved. (Option B)

(It includes Type III of DeBakey’s classification)

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with back pain, and imaging shows a thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm starting at the sixth intercostal space and extending to just above the renal arteries. According to the Crawford classification, which type does this aneurysm correspond to?
questions.explanation:
Type

Involvement

I

Descending thoracic aorta to above renal arteries.

II

Descending thoracic aorta to below renal arteries.

III

From the sixth intercostal space to below renal arteries.

IV

The entire abdominal aorta from the twelfth intercostal space to the aortic bifurcation.

V

Portion of the thoracic aorta below the sixth intercostal space to above renal arteries.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6.0 cm in diameter, detected during routine surveillance. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Surveillance
  • Small AAAs (3.0–3.9 cm): Monitor every 2–3 years using ultrasound.
  • Medium AAAs (4.0–5.4 cm): Monitor every 6–12 months with ultrasound.
  • Large AAAs (≥5.5 cm): Surgical intervention recommended; if not, frequent imaging and clinical review.

Medical Management

Risk Factor Modification:

  • Smoking Cessation
  • Blood Pressure Control
  • Cholesterol Management: Statins recommended.

Surgical Intervention

Indications for Surgery:

  • Aneurysm Diameter ≥ 5.5 cm (High risk of rupture)
  • Rapid Growth: >0.5 cm increase in six months.
  • Symptomatic AAAs: Consider surgery.

Surgical Options:

  • Open Surgical Repair: Using a Dacron graft which is durable and has higher morbidity.
  • Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR): Less invasive, requires long-term surveillance for complications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of bacterial endocarditis presents with sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. A CT scan of the head is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the haemorrhage in this patient?

A 58-year-old male presents with a pulsatile mass in the right groin following recent arterial catheterisation. Doppler ultrasound reveals an aneurysm. Which characteristic best describes this type of aneurysm?

options.label: A
options.text: Involves all three arterial wall layers

options.label: C
options.text: Wall composed of fibrous tissue only

questions.correct_answer: C. Wall composed of fibrous tissue only
questions.explanation:
Aspect

True Aneurysm

False (Pseudoaneurysm)

Definition

Involves all three layers of the arterial wall.

Involves only a layer of fibrous tissue outside the vessel. (Option A ruled out)

Wall Structure

Intima, media, and adventitia are involved.

Only fibrous tissue surrounds the breach.

Morphology

Fusiform or saccular.

Typically spherical or ovoid.(Option B ruled out)

Aetiology

Atherosclerosis, genetic conditions.

Trauma, surgery, or arterial puncture.(Option D ruled out)

Clinical Features

May be asymptomatic until complications arise.

Often presents with a pulsatile mass or pain.

Common Locations

Large arteries (e.g., aorta, iliac).

Peripheral arteries (e.g., femoral, popliteal).

Diagnosis

Detected by ultrasound, CT, and MRI.

Detected by ultrasound or angiography.

Management

Surgical repair or endovascular techniques.

Repair or percutaneous methods (e.g., thrombin injection).

Type of Aneurysm

Characteristics

Common Locations

Associated Conditions

Fusiform Aneurysm

Dilation affects the entire circumference of the vessel

Abdominal aorta, iliac

Atherosclerosis

Saccular Aneurysm

Dilation affects only part of the vessel circumference

Cerebral arteries, aortic

Atherosclerosis, infection

Mycotic Aneurysm

Caused by infection (Bacterial)

Usually cerebral or aortic

Endocarditis, septicemia

Aortic Root Aneurysm

Dilates the aortic root, leading to aortic regurgitation

Aortic root

Connective tissue disorders, syphilis

Popliteal Aneurysm

Most common peripheral aneurysm

Behind the knee

Atherosclerosis, embolisation

Femoral Aneurysm

Can be true or false, often related to surgery

Groin area

Post-surgical complication

Iliac Aneurysm

Often coexists with AAA

Iliac arteries

Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms (AAA)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe abdominal pain that is disproportionate to physical examination findings. He also reports vomiting and the passage of blood in his stool. Given his history and clinical presentation, which artery is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Description

Definition
  • Sudden reduction in blood supply to the intestines, leading to ischemia and potential necrosis.
  • Commonly involves the Superior mesenteric artery (SMA).

Clinical Features
  • Pain: Severe, sudden-onset abdominal pain disproportionate to physical findings.
  • Others: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bloody stools, shock.

Risk Factors
  • Cardiovascular: Atrial fibrillation, recent MI, heart failure.
  • Vascular: Atherosclerosis, vasculitis.
  • Others: Hypercoagulable states.

Radiological Features

CT Angiography: Preferred diagnostic tool; reveals SMA occlusion, String of sausage sign, bowel wall thickening, pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas.

Management
  • Initial: IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, pain control.
  • Definitive: Anticoagulation (e.g., IV heparin), surgical embolectomy, bowel resection. Vasodilators (e.g., papaverine) can be used intra-arterially to relieve vasospasm.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with episodic colour changes in her fingers triggered by cold temperatures and stress. The episodes follow a characteristic sequence. What is the correct sequence of events in the skin colour changes seen in the Raynaud phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Category

Description

Definition

Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by episodic reduction in blood flow, typically in the fingers, triggered by cold exposure or stress.

Clinical Features
  • Pallor: Skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow.
  • Cyanosis: Skin turns blue or purple due to deoxygenation of blood.
  • Rubor: Skin turns red as blood flow returns, often with swelling and tingling.
  • Cold Sensitivity: Cold, numb fingers.
  • Pain: Pain during the cyanotic phase.
  • Swelling and Tingling: Occurs in the rubor phase.

Types
  • Primary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Disease):
    • Occurs without underlying disease.
    • More common and has a better prognosis.
  • Secondary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Syndrome):
    • Occurs due to an underlying condition (e.g., scleroderma, lupus).
    • Often more severe.

Management
  • Lifestyle Modifications: Avoid cold exposure, stress reduction, and smoking cessation.
  • Medications: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine), alpha-blockers (e.g., prazosin), and other vasodilators.
  • Avoidance of Triggers: Avoid cold, beta-blockers, and caffeine.
  • Advanced Treatments: Surgical sympathectomy for severe cases.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Presentation and History: Based on symptoms and triggers.
  • Nailfold Capillaroscopy: To examine capillary changes.
  • Blood Tests: To identify underlying autoimmune or connective tissue diseases.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe pain in his left leg. The leg appears pale and feels cold to the touch, and the patient is unable to move or feel his toes. On examination, no pulses are detectable below the knee. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe pain in his left leg, which has become cold and pale. On examination, there is an absence of distal pulses. Imaging reveals a large saddle embolus at the aortic bifurcation. What is the most appropriate catheter to use for embolectomy in this case?

A 60-year-old male with end-stage renal disease is scheduled for the creation of a surgically created arteriovenous (AV) fistula to facilitate long-term hemodialysis. Which of the following is the most commonly used type of AV fistula for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Purpose
  • Used for hemodialysis
  • Provides high blood flow for effective dialysis

Site Selection
  • Prefer distal placement
  • Non-dominant arm is typically used

Arterial Quality

Requires a strong arterial pulse for success

Vein Preservation

Avoid placing venous lines in the arm intended for fistula

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents with intense pain in his left leg along with the following lesion. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Venous ulcer

(Option B)

Arterial ulcer

(Option C)

Neuropathic ulcer

(Option A)

Pressure ulcer

(Option D)

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful, distal pulses are not palpable, associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

Also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients.

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a 12-year history of smoking presents with severe rest pain and discoloration of the left lower limb's digits as shown below. He has experienced worsening pain in this limb for the past 2 days, following 3 months of discomfort. What is the appropriate management for this condition?

A 56-year-old male presents with sudden pain and numbness in his right lower limb for 1 day. On examination, the limb is cold and pale and exhibits loss of sensory and mild motor functions. Doppler studies reveal only venous signals. What grade of Rutherford's classification is this case?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Category

Sensory loss

Motor deficit

Arterial doppler signals

Venous doppler signals

Prognosis

I

(Option A)

Viable

none

none

Audible

Audible

No immediate threat

IIA

(Option B)

Marginally Threatened

None or minimal (toes)

none

Inaudible

Audible

Salvageable if promptly treated

IIB

(Option C)

Immediately threatened

More than toes

Mild/moderate

Inaudible

Audible

Salvageable with immediate revascularisation

III

(Option D)

Irreversible

Profound or insensate

Paralyzed

Inaudible

Inaudible

Limb is irreversibly damaged, major tissue loss, and amputation.

Stage

Description

Stage I

Asymptomatic

Stage IIA

Mild intermittent claudication (can walk >200 meters)

Stage IIB

Moderate to severe intermittent claudication (can only walk 200 meters or less)

Stage III

Rest pain

Stage IV

Critical limb ischemia leading to ulceration + gangrene.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chronic smoker presents with lower limb pain during walking for 2 weeks. Examination reveals an ankle-to-brachial systolic pressure ratio of 0.7. What is the correct interpretation of this finding?
questions.explanation:
ABI / ABPI = Systolic BP in the Ankle/ Systolic BP in the arm

Value

Interpretation

0.1 - 0.4

Critical limb ischemia (Option A)

0.5 - 0.9

Intermittent claudication (Option B)

1.0 - 1.2

Normal (Option C)

> 1.2

Calcified vessels (seen in patients with DM, End stage renal disease) (Option D)

questions.text: What is the most specific investigation of choice for peripheral arterial disease?

A 65-year-old man presents with pain in his right calf that occurs after walking 200 meters and is relieved by rest. The pain does not occur when he is at rest or when he walks shorter distances. Based on Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication, which grade best describes this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Description

Grade 0: Asymptomatic (Option A ruled out) 

No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise

Grade I: Mild claudication (Option B ruled out)

Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade II: Moderate claudication (option C)

Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade III: Severe claudication (Option D ruled out)

Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain

Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with pain in his hands and feet, which worsens with cold exposure. He has a history of heavy smoking. On examination, he has ulcers on his fingers and toes. Angiography reveals "corkscrew" collaterals and segmental occlusions. Which of the following conditions is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Buerger's Disease

(Option B)

Atherosclerosis

(Option C)

Age of onset

Usually <45 years

Typically >50 years

Gender predominance

Strong male predominance

Male > Female

Risk factors

Heavy smoking (essential for diagnosis)

Smoking, hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia

Pathophysiology

Inflammatory thrombosis

Lipid accumulation, inflammation, plaque formation

Vessels affected

Small and medium-sized arteries and veins

Large and medium-sized arteries

Distribution

Upper and lower extremities equally

Lower extremities > Upper extremities

Progression

Acute episodes with periods of remission

Gradual onset, chronic course

Diagnosis

Angiography shows "corkscrew" collaterals, segmental occlusions

Angiography shows irregular narrowing, calcification

Treatment

Smoking cessation is essential but has a limited role in revascularization.

Risk factor modification, antiplatelet therapy, revascularisation

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of severe pain, numbness, and coldness in his left leg. On examination, the left leg appears pale, and no pulse is palpable below the femoral artery. What is the most probable cause of this acute peripheral arterial occlusion?
questions.explanation:
• Atherosclerosis (Most common)
  • Embolism
  • Thrombosis
  • Trauma
  • Vasculitis (e.g., Buerger’s disease)
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia
  • Arterial dissection
  • Extrinsic compression

Vessel

Common Sites of Obstruction

Related Manifestations/Findings

Aorta

Infrarenal aorta

Bilateral lower limb ischemia, absent femoral pulses

Iliac arteries

Common iliac bifurcation

Unilateral lower limb ischemia, absent femoral pulse

Pain in the buttock is due to a block in the common iliac or aortoiliac segment (30%), often associated with impotence

and is called as Leriche's syndrome.

Femoral artery

Common femoral artery

Calf claudication, absent popliteal and distal pulses

Popliteal artery

Adductor canal

Calf and foot ischemia, absent pedal pulses

Tibial arteries

Proximal or mid-calf

Foot ischemia, absent pedal pulses

Subclavian artery

Proximal subclavian

Arm ischemia, absent radial/ulnar pulses

Subclavian steal syndrome:

Obstruction of the first part of the subclavian artery can cause reverse blood flow through the vertebral artery, providing collateral circulation to the arm but affecting the posterior brain and upper limb, with steal being occult, partial, or complete.

Brachial artery

Mid-humerus level

Forearm and hand ischemia, absent radial/ulnar pulses
